./.title: Introduction
./.body:
The Gear Programming Language
Welcome.  By opening...err... navigating your browser to this book, you've taken your first step on an exciting journey.  If you hadn't guessed by the title, this book will teach you about the Gear Programming Language.  It will also (hopefully) entertain you along the way.
Your probably wondering why the world needs another programming langauge, after all, there are so many already!  But languages, like tools, are each made for a different purpose.  Gear was primarly designed as an embeddable scripting langaugage.  That means you can expose your applications functionality to your uses allowing them extend your app for good or evil purposes.
The contents of this book focus on the Gear language itself.  If you want to know more about embedding Gear, then checkout the embedders guide.
Hello World
No programming language book is complete without the famous Hello World program.
The code snippet below isn't an image, its a live text editor prepopulated with a Gear program.  This book will contain interactive snippets of code like the one below to illustrate examples and allow you to experiment with the langauge.
print('Hello World')

If you're having problems with the snippet, then you should try using a modern desktop browser.  This site is not intended for older browers or browsers running on a toaster.
License
Gear is free software and is provided with no guarantees as stated in its license.  We take no responsiblily for lost or corrupted data, CPU fires, or monitor explosion.

getting-started.html.title: Installation and Setup

chapter-2/message_passing.html.title: 1. Message Passing
chapter-2/message_passing.html.body:
Message Passing

  I’m sorry that I long ago coined the term “objects” … because it gets many people to focus on the lesser idea.  The big idea is “messaging” …
  Alan Kay 


Gear gives complete control over method resolution.  It does not restrict your application to fit within a hierarchy.
Gear encourages a functional style of programming which means you are encouraged to send immutable messages when possible.  For example, you can sort a list in place using the sort! method, but you are encouraged to create a new sorted copy instead using sort.
Messages that perform a destructive or "dangerous" action end with a bang !.  Be careful when sending these messages.
Introduction to Prototypes
In prototype inheritance there are no classes or instances, there are just objects.  Inheritance is performed by linking objects directly to other objects.  In Gear, inheritance is dynamic and the relationships can change at runtime.
Objects are composed of two things: slots and the prototype list.
The sender is the object that sends the message and the reciever is the object that can respond to the message.  In delegation the message is executed in the context of the sender.  In forwarding the message is executed in the context of the reciever.
Delegation
Every object maintains its own prototype list which is an ordered set of objects.  This list is used during message resolution:
When an object recieves a message it first checks if it can respond to it.  If it can, then it does so, if it cannot then it iterates through its prototype list until it finds an object that can respond to the message.  If there is no object that can respond to the message, then Object is checked.  If Object cannot respond to the message, then the process starts over with the unrecognizedMessage message.
You can modify an objects prototype list through the following messages:

appendDelegate!
prependDelegate!
insertDelegateAtIndex!
removeDelegateAtIndex!
getDelegateCount
getDelegates

Slots
Slots have two components: a label and a value.  The label must be an identifier, but the value can be any Gear type.  A slot can be accessed using the . operator.  In the example below, a slot is created/assigne/something OR OTHER figure out what to say...
Object.foo := 'bar'
Message Passing

  The big idea is “messaging” …
  Alan Kay 


Before a message is invoked, the message willSendMessage is invoked with the name of the message and the arguments.  If the function returns true, then the message is sent otherwise its not.  The default value returned is true - so all messages are sent.
After a message is invoked, the message didRecieveMessageis sent.
Object Creation
In Gear, objects can be created one of two ways: ex nihilo ("from nothing") or from an existing object.
The example below demonstrates an object being created ex nihilo:
new()
This object does not have any slots or parents.  Its effectively an empty object.
The following creates a object ex nihilo as well, however, a few things happen afterwards:

Object is added to the new objects parent slot list.
The method init is called on the new object and the arguments given to new are passed to it.

Object.new()
The init method can be thought of as the objects constructor.  Constructors in Gear are not special or different from any other method.  In fact, in Gear, any method that returns a new object can be thought of as a constructor.
You can make your own constructor by creating a new object, adding the original object to the parent prototype chain, and then returning the new object.  Below is the implementation of the new method provided by Gear.
proto Object
    fn new(args...)
        let self = new()
        self.appendProto(delegate: Object)
        self.init(...args) # Expand variable arguments.
        ret self
    end
end

chapter-2/builtin_types.html.title: 3. Builtin Types
chapter-2/builtin_types.html.body:
Builtin Types
Gear includes a small set of types out of the box.  This is because Gear was primarily designed as an embeddable programming language and it makes no assumptions about the needs of the application that hosts it.  Embedders are expected to provide their own libraries for their needs.
This chapter explains Gear's builtin types at a high level.  For an in-depth look at the entire standard library see the standard library documentation.
What follows is the complete list of Gear's builtin types:

Object
Number
Boolean
String
List
Map

Package Manager
If you need additional libraries, then use Gear's package manager gear up to acquire them.  This is especially useful if Gear is used standalone (e.g. from a non-embedded context).

chapter-2/number.html.title: 3.1 Number
chapter-2/number.html.body:
Numbers
Integers can be written in base 8 (octal), base 10 (decimal), and base 16 (hexidecimal).  Octal numbers are prefxed with 0c and hexidecmal numbers are prefixed with 0x.  Decimal numbers do not require a prefix.
0c217     # Base 8   (Octal)
12345     # Base 10  (Decimal)
0x91FF    # Base 16  (Hexidecimal)

Real numbers can be written with a decimal point or in scientific notation.
3.14159       # with decimal
1.54334E-34   # scientific notation

Numbers have arbitrary precision.
The following snippet demonstrates multiplying numbers outside the range 2^{31} (the range of a signed 32-bit integer).
234324234238949001 * 23503894021234234

Embedders Note
If you compile Gear from source you can disable arbitrary precision arithmetic and enable fixed width arithmetic by defining the GEAR_FIXED_ARITHMETIC in gear_config.h.

chapter-2/boolean.html.title: 3.2 Boolean
chapter-2/boolean.html.body:
Booleans
Booleans can be written with the literals true and false.
All values, including the integer zero, are truthy.  The only values that are falsey are false and nil.

chapter-2/string.html.title: 3.3 String
chapter-2/string.html.body:
Strings
Strings are immutable sequences of UTF-8 encoded unicode code points.  They can be written with single or double quotes.  There is no behavioral difference between them.  Which one you use is personal preference.
"This is a double quoted string"
'This is a single quoted string'

Since everything is an object in Gear that means methods can be called on them directly.  All of the objects provided by the standard library can be converted to strings using the toString method.
"Hello" concat(" world!")

Escaped Strings
Escapes sequences can be used to substitute a character with another character that may be more cumbersome to represent directly.  Gear supports many of the same escape sequences available in C and Java.
In the follow example the character sequence \n will be substituted for the byte 0x0A.
"Escaped string \n split by a new line"

All of the escape sequences supported by Gear are shown in the following table.



Escape Sequence
Character represented




\a
Alert (beep, bell)


\b
Backspace


\f
Formfreed


\n
Newline


\r
Carriage return


\t
Horizontal tab


\v
Vertical tab


\
Backslash


\'
Single quotation mark


\"
Double quotation mark


\0cnnn
The byte nnn interpreted as an octal


\0bn...
The byte n... interpreted as a binary digit


\0xhh...
The byte hh... interpreted as a hexadecimal number


\0Uhhhhhhhh
Unicode code point where h is a hexadecimal digit


\0uhhhh
Unicode code point below 10000 hexidecimal


\${expression}
Disables string interpolation for expression



Unescaped Strings
Unescaped strings or raw strings are strings where the substitution of escape sequences has been disabled.  They can be written by prefixing a string with an @.
The following example demontrates this feature for a double quoted string, but the behavior is the same for a single quoted string.
@"Unescaped string with a literal backslash 'n' at the end \n"

String Interpolation
String interpolation can be used to evaluate any arbitrary expression.  String interpolation only works for escaped strings.
"The sum of 2 + 2 is ${2 + 2}"

chapter-2/list.html.title: 3.3 List
chapter-2/list.html.body:
Lists
Lists are ordered sequences of values (also known as "elements").  They can be written with bracket literals and can contain any mix types.  The snippet below creates a mixed-type list of 3 elements.
[1, true, "Hello, World!"]

The empty list can be created with empty brackets [].
List Type
You can also create lists using the List type directly, but the convention is to use the literal syntax whenever possible.
let fruit = List new()
fruit push('apple')
fruit push('grape')
fruit push('watermelon')

Accessing Elements
List values can be randomly accessed using bracket notation.  They are indexed starting from one where index 1 is the first element, index 2 is the 2nd element, and so on.  Negative indices access elements from the end were index -1 accesses the last element, index -2 accesses the 2nd to last element, and so on.
let fruit = ['apple', 'grape', 'watermelon']
let apple = fruit[1]
let watermelon = fruit[-1]

Accessing index 0 will raise an "index out of bounds" exception.
In practice it is recommended to use the first and last messages to access the beginning and end of the list.
Iteration
You can iterate over a list using a for loop.
let fruit = ['apple', 'grape', 'watermelon']
for (element in fruit)
    print(element)
end

Alternatively, you can use messages like map and forEach to iterate.
['apple', 'grape', 'watermelon'].forEach(print)

chapter-2/dictionary.html.title: 3.3 Dictionary
chapter-2/dictionary.html.body:
Dictionary
Dictionaries are unordered key/value pairs.  Keys and values can be any type.
They can be written with curly bracket literals.  The snippet below creates a dictionary using the literal syntax.
{'apple': 'red', true: 1, 42: 'answer to life'}

The empty dictionary can be created with empty curly brackets {}.
Dict Type
You can also create dictionaries using the Dict type directly, but the convention is to use the literal syntax whenever possible.
let age = Dict new()
age insert('Jill', 23)
age insert('Bob', 51)
age insert('Sue', 17)

Lookup
Dictionary values can be accessed using theirs via bracket notation.  Accessing a key that does not exist when using bracket notation returns nil.
let fruit = ['apple', 'grape', 'watermelon']
let apple = fruit[1]
let watermelon = fruit[-1]

The bracket notation is identical to the lookup message.  In practice it is recommended to use the bracket notation when looking up keys.
You can also use the lookup! message to return a value for a given key.  The behavior of this message is the exact same as bracket notation, but if the key does not exist, then a "missing key" exception is raised.
To check if a key exists, use the hasKey message.  It returns the boolean true if the key exists and false if it does not.
Delete
TODO!
Iteration
You can iterate over a list using a for loop.
let fruit = ['apple', 'grape', 'watermelon']
for (key, value in fruit)
    print("key: ${key} value: ${value}")
end

Alternatively, you can use messages like map and forEach to iterate.
['apple', 'grape', 'watermelon'].forEach(
    fn(key, value)
        print("${key} = ${value}")
    end
)

chapter-2/comments.html.title: 2. Comments

chapter-3/embedding.html.title: 5. Functions
chapter-3/embedding.html.body:
Embedding
You might like to give your users the ability to extend or modify your application.  One way to do this is by using a shared object.  Unfortunatly shared objects have a few problems:

They must be recompiled for every platform.
They have unrestricted access to the system.
They share the applications memory space so a crash will bring down the whole application

Gear solves these problems by executing code in a sandboxed environment.  This means all code is run through a virtual machine and garbage collected).  This protects your applications memory and insulates it from crashes.
Users will not have unrestricted access to the system because the host can choose what functionality to expose to scripts.

chapter-2/objects.html.title: Declaration
chapter-2/objects.html.body:
Objects
Objects are comprised slots and a prototype list.  They can be created one of two ways: ex nihilo ("from nothing") or from an existing object.
The example below demonstrates an object being created ex nihilo:
new()
This object does not have any slots or parents.  Its effectively an empty object.
The following creates a object ex nihilo as well, however, a few things happen afterwards:

Object is added to the new objects parent slot list.
The method init is called on the new object and the arguments given to new are passed to it.

Object.new()
The init method can be thought of as the objects constructor.  Constructors in Gear are not special or different from any other method.  In fact, in Gear, any method that returns a new object can be thought of as a constructor.
You can make your own constructor by creating a new object, adding the original object to the parent prototype chain, and then returning the new object.  Below is the implementation of the new method provided by Gear.
proto Object
    fn new(args...)
        let self = new()
        self.appendProto(delegate: Object)
        self.init(...args) # Expand variable arguments.
        ret self
    end
end
